questions.text: A 60-year-old man came to the OPD with a persistent backache. Rectal examination revealed a single, hard, irregular nodule within his prostate. His prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level came to 100 ng/ml (normal < 3.0 ng/ml) and a CT scan showed several enlarged pelvic lymph nodes and multiple sclerotic lesions in his spine. Which of the following pairs of drugs would be the most appropriate for the patient at this time?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leuprolide and flutamide The patient’s signs and symptoms suggest prostate cancer and the exam results confirm the diagnosis of metastasized prostatic carcinoma. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the most used lab test for the early detection of prostate cancer, and spine metastases with prevalent necrotic lesions are the most common metastases of prostatic carcinoma. The mainstay of treatment for metastasized prostate cancer is hormonal therapy. Because cancer is testosterone-dependent , hormonal manipulation focuses on reducing testosterone levels.

Because they increase androgen secretion by antagonizing androgenic action in the pituitary, combination with orchiectomy or GnRH analogs is required to produce a full therapeutic effect. questions.text: A 58-year-old man complained to his physician of fatigue, drowsiness, dizziness, and palpitations. He was recently diagnosed with bladder obstruction due to benign prostatic hyperplasia and had been taking a drug for 2 weeks. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tamsulosin In a k/c/o Benign Hypertrophy of the Prostate (BHP) on treatment patient complaining of fatigability, drowsiness, dizziness, and palpitations is probably a side effect of Drug used in the treatment of Benign Hypertrophy of the Prostate (BHP). Tamsulosin is a selective α 1 antagonist frequently used to counteract bladder obstruction due to prostatic hyperplasia. Fatigue, sleepiness, and dizziness are common adverse effects as seen in this patient most likely related to the drug-induced hypotension , palpitations are infrequently reported and are most likely related to th e reflex tachycardia triggered by the drug-induced vasodilation.

Highyeild:

Benign Hypertrophy of the Prostate (BHP) - The urinary obstruction caused by BHP has a static component due to the increased size of the prostate and a dynamic component due to the increased tone of the bladder neck/prostate smooth muscle. Two classes of drugs are available: α1 adrenergic blockers (prazosin-like) : they decrease the tone of prostatic/bladder neck muscles . 5-αreductase inhibitor (finasteride/dutasteride) which arrests growth/reduces the size of the prostate Activation of α1 adrenoceptors in bladder trigone , prostate, and prostatic urethra increases smooth muscle tone , their blockade relaxes these structures, reducing dynamic obstruction , increasing urinary flow rate, and causing more complete emptying of the bladder in many patients of BHP. Voiding symptoms (hesitancy, narrowing of stream, dribbling, and increased residual urine) are relieved better than irritative symptoms like urgency, frequency, and nocturia. The α1 blockers afford faster (within 2 weeks) and greater symptomatic relief than finasteride which primarily affects the static component of obstruction and has a delayed onset taking nearly six months for clinical improvement. The α1 blockers do not affect prostate size but are more commonly used . However, the effects last only till the drug is given. Even with continued therapy, benefits may decline after a few years due to disease progression. They may be used concurrently with finasteride. Terazosin, doxazosin, alfuzosin, and tamsulosin are the preferred α1 blockers because of once-daily dosing. There is some evidence that terazosin and doxazosin promote apoptosis in the prostate. Tamsulosin appears to cause fewer vascular side effects because of relative α1A/α1D selectivity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man recently diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia was scheduled for surgery. Which of the following drug classes would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Antimuscarinics In a k/c/o Benign prostatic hyperplasia patient antimuscarinics are absolutely contraindicated as they can precipitate acute urinary retention in BPH patients.

Highyeild:

Antimuscarinic drugs relax the detrusor muscle, so voiding of the bladder becomes more difficult. This can be especially dangerous in patients with prostatic hyperplasia who already have difficulty in micturition, due to prostate-induced narrowing of the urethra. In these patients, antimuscarinic drugs can precipitate acute urinary retention. However, this relaxant action can be beneficial for increasing bladder capacity and controlling detrusor hyperreflexia in neurogenic bladder/enuresis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Alpha-1 blockers such as prazosin are indicated in prostatic hyperplasia , as they relax the internal sphincter of the bladder. Option: C. Beta-blockers tend to contract the smooth muscle, as they block β2 receptor−mediated relaxation . However, these drugs have little influence on nonvascular smooth muscles and are mainly under parasympathetic control. Option: D. Alpha-2 agonists- activate α2 receptors , which are mainly presynaptic. This activation in turn can decrease the release of norepinephrine, thereby decreasing the contractility of the internal sphincter of the bladder.

questions.text: Rahul, a 34-year-old man was referred to a psychiatrist because of irritability, worrying thoughts, palpitations, dry mouth, and insomnia of 1-month duration. The man had a history of alcohol abuse, but he was able to quit 1 year ago after psychological counseling and drug therapy. Recently, he suffered from erectile dysfunction, treated with sildenafil. A provisional diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder was made, and cognitive behavioral therapy with drug treatment was prescribed. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Buspirone A provisional diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder was made. Buspirone does not cause Sexual side effects and can be used in this patient with H/O erectile dysfunction.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man suffering from benign prostatic hyperplasia was admitted to the hospital because of severe suprapubic pain and an inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours. On questioning, he said he had been taking diphenhydramine for a few days to relieve itching. Which of the following actions most likely mediated the adverse effect of the drug in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Constriction of the bladder's external sphincter

options.label: D
options.text: Relaxation of the bladder's internal sphincter

questions.correct_answer: A. Relaxation of the detrusor muscle
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Relaxation of the detrusor muscle A Benign prostatic hyperplasia patient with acute urinary retention ( severe suprapubic pain and an inability to pass urine for the past 24 hours.) with a history of taking diphenhydramine ( first-generation antihistamine ) points towards its antimuscarinic action which relaxes the detrusor muscle and can precipitate acute urinary retention in BPH patients.

Highyeild:

Antimuscarinic drugs relax the detrusor muscle, so voiding of the bladder becomes more difficult. This can be especially dangerous in patients with prostatic hyperplasia who already have difficulty in micturition, due to prostate-induced narrowing of the urethra. In these patients, antimuscarinic drugs can precipitate acute urinary retention. However, this relaxant action can be beneficial for increasing bladder capacity and controlling detrusor hyperreflexia in neurogenic bladder/enuresis.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Constriction of the bladder external sphincter -The bladder external sphincter includes striated muscle and is not under the control of the autonomic nervous system. Option: C. Constriction of the prostate capsule- The prostate capsule is constricted via α1 receptors . Most antihistamines have negligible effects on these receptors. Option: D. Relaxation of the bladder internal sphincter- The bladder internal sphincter has mainly α1 receptors . Most antihistamines have negligible effects on these receptors.
